_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive  Summary   For  Schnucks  Mid  States  Dairy



    Describe  Accidental  Release  Prevention  and Emergency  Policies
     
     This company recognizes management's responsibility in protecting it's employees, equipment, 
property, and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are very important. The 
control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the 
facility.
    
    To accomplish the Company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established a 
Plant Safety Program. The objectives of this program are to achieve maximum efficiency and 
safety performance.
    
    One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and 
implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency programs which are designed to 
comply with OSHA's  Process Safety Management  standard ( 29 CFR 1910.119 )  and EPA's  
Risk Management Program ( 40 CFR  Part 68).
    
    The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response program is to prevent 
the occurrence , and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as 
well as fires, explosions , and other types of catastrophic events.
    
    
    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled

                This company operates a food production facility at this location. The facility operates one 
                ammonia refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities. The amount of 
                ammonia ( CAS #7662-41-7 ) contained in the system  is in excess of 10,000 pounds. Since an 
                ammonia release from the system  could pose a risk of offsite public impact, and the system is 
                regulated  under the OSHA  PSM standard , the system is subject to the Program 3 requirements  
                of the EPA's Risk Management Program.

                In the ammonia refrigeration system, ammonia vapor is fed from vessels at low pres

sures to low 
                stage compressors. The compressed vapors from the low stage compressors are fed to vessels 
                operating at intermediate pressures and then fed to the high stage compressors. The high pressure
                ammonia vapor flows from the high stage compressors to the condensers where heat is removed, 
                turning the vapor into a high pressure liquid. The high pressure liquid from the condensers is 
                collected in a high pressure receiver.

                The high pressure liquid collected in the high pressure receiver is circulated to various  
                pressure  vessels , where it is pumped to the evaporators ( storage tanks, freezers, air handling 
                units, etc. ) located throughout the plant. The ammonia liquid absorbs heat at these various 
                evaporators, changing from a liquid to a vapor. The low pressure ammonia vapor is then sent 
                back to the appropriate vessel via vapor headers.

             
    Summary of Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios
     
    The worst-case release scenario at the facility is a release of pressurized liquid ammonia from the 
    60 inch  by 14 foot High Pressure Receiver located in the Ammonia Machinery Room. The 
Receiver has a capacity of 10,000 pounds of ammonia. However, the plant has administrative 
controls in place that limit the ammonia inventory in that receiver to a maximum of 40% of the 
capacity. Therefore the worst - case release would involve the release of 4142 pounds of 
ammonia over a ten minute period due to the failure of the receiver. The ammonia could travel 
0.99 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.
    
    The worst-case release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:
    

    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture of this receiver. 
    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.
    Pressure safety relief valves limit operating pressures in this rece

iver
    The facility has a P.M. program to maintain the integrity of the pressure vessels.
    The system is maintained and operated by qualified personnel, and
    The facility has dual pressure sensors that shut the system down before reaching the set pressure 
of the relief valves.
    
    The alternative release scenario involves the release of 1325 pounds of ammonia over a five 
minute period due to the rupture of a _ inch high temperature recirculated liquid pipe. This line 
feeds ammonia to an air handling unit. The ammonia could travel  0.31 miles  before dispersing 
enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.
    
    The alternative release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:
    
    The recirculative liquid lines are in areas that could help to contain such a release.
    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture of these lines.
    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.
    The facility has a P.M. program to maintain the integrity of the system.
    The system is maintained and operated by qualified personnel, and 
    The facility has procedures in place to stop all flow promotion devices in the refrigeration system 
quickly.

        

    Description  of the Accidental  Release Prevention Program
    
               The prevention program consists of the following elements:
 

    Employee Participation: The program involves the employees in establishing and 
    implementing the program. Employees were involved in all process hazard analysis and have 
access to the program.
    Process Safety Information : Information has been collected which enables employees to identify 
and understand the potential hazards in the system. Information includes MSDS and the 
design of the system.
    Process Hazard Analysis: An involved study using the " What - If  Technique" has been 
conducted to look at the system and identify potential hazards.
    Operating Procedures: Procedures have been developed to safely operate the ammonia system.
    Training : A training program has been established to

train employees in the safe operation and 
maintenance of the ammonia system.
    Contractors: All contractors are evaluated before they perform work on the ammonia system.
    Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup review is conducted for all new project to verify that all 
safety programs are in place, that training has been performed and construction completed 
according to design standards before the project is put into use.
    Mechanical Integrity: This program ensures that the ammonia system is built and maintained 
using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected failures.
    Hot Work Permit: These procedures ensure that a permit is obtained  prior to cutting, welding,or 
burning
    Management of Change: This procedure is designed to ensure that all changes to the ammonia 
system are properly reviewed before starting.
    Incident Investigation: This procedure ensures that any incident , or near miss,  is investigated, 
and reviewed using an investigation team.
    Compliance Audits: These are procedures to audit programs to make sure they are in place and 
working properly.
                   


    Five - Year  Accident History
    
    No ammonia related incident were identified for the facility in the previous five years which 
resulted in any on -site or off-site consequences.
    
    Description of the Emergency Response Program
    
    An emergency response program has established at the facility. The program consists of action to 
be taken in the event of emergencies including an ammonia spill.
    
    The emergency response program consists of the following elements:
    

    Organization Plan and Responsibilities
    Communication Procedures 
    Fire Aid Procedures
    Evacuation Plans
    Training Procedures
    

    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
    
    Twenty Eight  recommendations  were made as a result of the PHA which was completed on Jan. 
20,1999 . These include equipment modifications , procedure modifications and labeling. These 
recommendations have been evaluated and are in the proce
